title: nplays On-Line Movie Delivery
claim: Netflix Inc. Chief Executive Reed Hastings on Wednesday downplayed prospects for online delivery of movies, saying licensing snarls with movie studios would hold up consumer adoption long after the technology becomes widely available.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Netflix Inc. Chief Executive Reed Hastings on Wednesday downplayed prospects for online delivery of movies, saying licensing snarls with movie studios would hold up consumer adoption long after the technology becomes widely available.   Hastings said Netflix, the online DVD rental leader, expects the DVD format to dominate movie distribution for years to come as studios work out business plans for online distribution.   “Media formats are led by not what people want but format profitability,” he said.   As long as movie studios are reaping huge profits — as much as $15 per DVD — from DVD sales that totaled more than $14 billion last year, studios have little incentive to adopt online or on demand delivery models that will pay them far less, Hastings said.   “We recognized that DVD would dominate for ... 10 to 15 to 20 years,” he said. “That won’t last forever. Eventually piracy will rise and the movie industry will allow more downloading to people like us.”   Netflix plans to set aside 1 percent to 2 percent of revenues in the next five years to make way for online delivery on “several platforms,” including a pact already signed with TiVo, Hastings said.   The company, based in Los Gatos, California, plans to roll out limited online delivery later this year. “We will launch something this year and it will be totally underwhelming,” he said.   “Our view is that we don’t want to end up with the AOL irony,” in which the Internet service provider failed to recognize the importance of broadband before it became mainstream.   Hastings said Netflix is betting that online delivery of films won’t take off “for a couple of years, and that allows us to grow very large on the DVD side.”   With a target subscriber base of 20 million, Netflix could fend off competition for online download services by what will likely be a wide range of competitors, from Comcast Corp. to Walt Disney Co., while negotiating licensing agreements, he said.   Netflix is betting that online download capability will penetrate the market relatively slowly, making it necessary for online rental companies to bridge the technology gap.   “Consumers would choose a service that gave them downloading on the movies that were enabled for that and DVDs on the movies that were not,” he said. “That would be the differentiator during the transition period.”   Among the possible projects the company may consider during the transition to online delivery was adding original content, he said. title: mit-Cell Phones Seen Challenging Sony Game Handheld
claim: Cell phone video games will rival games on mainstream handhelds like the Sony Corp. PSP by late 2006, executives of some of the top phone game publishers said on Wednesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Cell phone video games will rival games on mainstream handhelds like the Sony Corp. PSP by late 2006, executives of some of the top phone game publishers said on Wednesday.   The cost and complexity of developing such games makes consolidation inevitable, the chief executives of private publishers Sorrent and In-Fusio and top mobile executives of Electronic Arts Inc. and the Walt Disney Co. said in a panel discussion at the Reuters Technology Summit.   Handhelds like Sony Corp.’s PSP and Nintendo Co. Ltd.’s DS currently far outstrip cell phones in terms of graphics capability and processing power. But before long, those executives said, phones will be equal to the challenge.   “We think if we track those out we’re looking at devices pushing PSP kind of quality in late 2006, early 2007,” said John Batter, general manager of EA Mobile.   And his peers suggested that when that happens, most people will be more likely to carry one device.   “I think it is a reasonable bet that if you are going to carry one device it is going to be a phone device from your phone company,” said Larry Shapiro, general manager of Disney Mobile. Disney’s ESPN is launching its own brand of cell phone service later this year.   While objective figures are somewhat hard to come by, Gilles Raymond, the co-CEO of In-Fusio, suggested the wireless games market was a 1.6 billion euro ($2.11 billion) business worldwide, with 75 percent growth in 2005 over 2004 and 60 percent growth in 2006 over 2005.   Dealing with all that growth effectively means smaller players must combine to survive, the executives said.   “Everybody who’s in this business recognizes there’s going to be consolidation,” said Greg Ballard, CEO of Sorrent. “The struggle for a company like ours is that we stay above the water and become a consolidator rather than a consolidatee.”    Much of the cost in the wireless game business at the moment is in porting — the process of making a game work on different phones. Because handsets are so different, each game must be reprogramed for each phone — as many as 150 different models now and potentially up to 200 by the end of 2005.   At a cost of about $1,000 to $2,000 per port, the obstacle is significant.   “I call it the worst barrier to entrance,” In-Fusio’s Raymond said.   Most of the speakers called porting their worst difficulty, except for Ballard, who said Sorrent was actually set up to have expertise and ability in fast, high-volume porting.   “That has been one of our compelling advantages in the marketplace,” he said. “In an ideal world the complexity continues until everybody goes out of business except us.”   For the future, the panel saw the mobile games market maturing into a full-fledged business with operating margins of anywhere from 20 percent to 30 percent.   But as with anything in wireless, they also agreed that much of the game market’s future success depends on the willingness of the carriers to help.   “It is a painful process and carriers are largely in a position to help accelerate or decelerate the growth of the market,” EA’s Batter said. title: mit-Nokia Minds Its Finances But Open to Big Deals
claim: Mobile phone maker Nokia, which boasts of one of the strongest balance sheets in the world of high tech, would be prepared to take on more risk to finance potential mergers, a top executive said on Wednesday.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Mobile phone maker Nokia, which boasts of one of the strongest balance sheets in the world of high tech, would be prepared to take on more risk to finance potential mergers, a top executive said on Wednesday.   “We’ve always wanted to make sure that we have financial flexibility to execute on our current business, and should we find any opportunities that we think would be value-creating, we could do acquisitions,” Chief Financial Officer Rick Simonson told the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco.   The Finnish mobile phone giant has been reluctant to use its cash or stock to fund large deals, preferring to invest heavily in research and development of new products while making occasional small technology acquisitions.   But rapid consolidation sweeping across the U.S. technology sector from telecommunications to computer hardware and software has forced every major company to review its openness to deal-making so as not to be eclipsed by bigger players.   “I think we have the flexibility to do whatever would be feasible,” he said of his appetite for big deals. “We don’t have any acquisitions to announce, so I can’t tell you anything.”   Echoing comments from other leading gear makers such as Cisco Systems Inc., Simonson said the global telecommunications market has been long overdue for a shakeout, with too much research and too many products chasing falling demand.   But he said the industry has proved enormously resistant to a major consolidation to shrink the number of players that might help the industry become more profitable.    Nokia held 11.8 billion euros, or US$15.4 billion, in cash and securities last year — the third-richest cash position in high tech after Microsoft Corp. and Intel Corp. .   This allows Nokia to buy back its shares aggressively while paying the highest dividend in the wireless equipment sector.   Simonson, a former investment banker, said he has long opposed taking on large amounts of debt just because its blue-chip corporate status would allow it to do so.   Reflecting its financial strength and the cleanest balance sheet of any global technology company, Nokia has negative net debt and also negative gearing, the ratio of debt to equity.   But he said he wanted to remain flexible in taking on debt if business opportunities presented themselves.   “We’re not going to be a slave to some magic gearing number,” Simonson said.   The first priority for cash is to fund more than $3 billion a year in research and development and also to finance marketing programs to expand its brand globally, he said.   However, critics say Nokia has been overly cautious in taking advantage of its balance sheet to invest in new business prospects.   Managing cash flow levels and generating additional cash at the company, which produced nearly 200 million phones last year, is the company’s biggest priority, Simonson said. Nokia focuses on cash flow rather than profit margins, even though it commands the highest margins in the industry by all measures.  News from the Reuters Technology Summit will be delivered

title: mit-Symantec, Veritas Shrug Off Merger Skepticism
claim: Symantec Corp., the top maker of computer security software, and Veritas Software Corp. on Wednesday dismissed investor skepticism of their $13.5 billion merger and said they expected to integrate the companies in less than a year after the deal closes.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Symantec Corp., the top maker of computer security software, and Veritas Software Corp. on Wednesday dismissed investor skepticism of their $13.5 billion merger and said they expected to integrate the companies in less than a year after the deal closes.   Symantec Chairman and Chief Executive John Thompson said the combined company would probably do more small acquisitions in the future after Symantec and Veritas, a top maker of data storage management software, have successfully integrated.   “My sense is that we’ll continue to look at small things, but in terms of large transactions, we are not focused there at all,” Thompson said at the Reuters Technology Summit here.   Veritas Chief Executive Gary Bloom said integrating the two companies could take between six and 12 months, during which time they would not be inclined to consider other acquisitions. The deal is expected to close this summer.   Asked if there was anything to cause Symantec, known for its Norton anti-virus software, to abandon its acquisition of Veritas, Thompson said, “Nothing at all.”   “While Wall Street reacted more lukewarm to the deal than we might have anticipated, customers and employees have been more than enthusiastic about it,” Thompson said.   Many investors have questioned the logic of Symantec’s acquisition, pushing the share prices of both companies sharply lower.   Symantec has said the aim of the deal, announced in December, was to give it a broader product line and help companies cut costs by using one supplier to blend security with data management.   The deal will also give Symantec a stronger foothold in the corporate software market and a sales staff at Veritas that is trained to sell to larger companies.   Thompson said he was “comfortable” with Symantec’s current fourth-quarter outlook given on Jan. 19.   Symantec on Jan. 19 forecast revenue between $690 million and $710 million for its fourth quarter ending April 1 and earnings, excluding items, of 24 cents a share. That outlook topped Wall Street estimates at the time.    Bloom will be vice-chairman and president of the combined company, which would be the fourth largest software company in the world by revenues.   Thompson stuck to a “high-teens” sales growth target for the combined company in fiscal year 2006, but said he would be let down if the company did not perform better.   “Personally, I’d be disappointed if that’s all we deliver,” he said about the 2006 sales outlook.   Analysts forecast fiscal 2006 revenues of $3.08 billion   versus fiscal year 2005 sales of $2.58 billion, according to Reuters Estimates.   Symantec’s stock is down about 34 percent since early December, though analysts have said the weaker share price is a buying opportunity given the strong demand for computer security software products and the continued threat of Internet viruses.   Thompson said a combined product offering of the two companies could be rolled-out nine months to 15 months after the deal closes, but said cross-selling of Symantec and Veritas products would start immediately after the acquisition closes.   The combined company was still considering its cash strategy but is likely to continue buying back shares, Thompson said, adding the strategy would be put into place after the company’s board is assembled. That will happen once the deal is closed, he said.   “Both companies have been aggressive repurchasers ... And I don’t expect that to change,” Thompson said. title: ced to Forgo Profit for 5 Yrs if Needed
claim: Online DVD rental leader Netflix Inc. is prepared to sacrifice profits for up to five years in order to win up to 20 million U.S. subscribers and fend off major rivals such as Blockbuster and Amazon.com, its CEO said on Wednesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Online DVD rental leader Netflix Inc. is prepared to sacrifice profits for up to five years in order to win up to 20 million U.S. subscribers and fend off major rivals such as Blockbuster and Amazon.com, its CEO said on Wednesday.   Chief Executive Reed Hastings said Netflix, the pioneer of online DVD rental, could capture as much as 20 percent of the U.S. market by extending the strategy it embarked on in October to run at break-even while spending heavily on marketing.   “Correct,” Hastings said when asked if he was prepared to sacrifice profitability for as much as five years in order to reach 20 million customers, up from 2.6 million currently. “That’s true. We haven’t given any guidance on it, so therefore, it’s possible,” he told the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco.   “We can prove that it’s a rational investment because we spend between $35 and $38 per subscriber,” Hastings said, referring to the cost of gaining new customers. The typical Netflix customer subscribes for about two years and generates $100 of profit on average, he said.   Netflix, based in Los Gatos, California, expenses its subscriber marketing costs in the quarter in which they are incurred, in contrast to the breakneck spending during the dot-com boom of the 1990s when many online services spent without accounting for such costs.   Analysts had been expecting the company to post net losses in the coming two years, according to a consensus of analysts by Reuters Estimates.   Netflix is in the midst of an aggressive price war with Blockbuster, which offers customers unlimited DVDs, three at a time, plus coupons for in-store use for $14.99 a month. Netflix offers comparable service, with no store coupons, for $17.99.   Hastings has been predicting that online retailer Amazon.com would enter the U.S. online rental market shortly. Amazon launched an online rental service in Britain in December.   He said Netflix aimed to capture 20 percent of the 100 million U.S. households that own DVD players. title: dent as Rival Offers Cheap Phones
claim: Mobile phone maker Nokia expects that a new $40 phone from rival Motorola Inc. will do little to dent its dominant -- and highly profitable -- position in the low-cost phone market, Nokia's chief financial officer said on Wednesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Mobile phone maker Nokia expects that a new $40 phone from rival Motorola Inc. will do little to dent its dominant — and highly profitable — position in the low-cost phone market, Nokia’s chief financial officer said on Wednesday.   “We’ve been saying for years there’s money to be made at the low end of the market,” Rick Simonson, Nokia’s CFO, said at the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco, when asked about the expected impact of the new Motorola phone and the viability of the low-end phone market. .   “We’re going to continue to bother with the low-end and we’re going to continue to do well,” said Simonson, noting that 20 percent of Nokia’s profit from mobile phones comes from models priced at 100 euros or less.   “Obviously we must have our pricing right,” he said.   Simonson’s remarks follow last month’s announcement by Motorola, Nokia’s biggest rival, that it planned to enter the low-price market with a phone selling for under $40 and aimed at burgeoning wireless markets such as Asia and Latin America.   Motorola’s new $40 phone is slightly cheaper than Nokia’s low-end phones, a market that generally refers to phones costing under $50.   Nokia is the main supplier of low-end phones, but analysts have speculated that the Motorola announcement, which includes plans to manufacture 6 million inexpensive phones later this year, could prompt a price war.   Simonson said that Nokia has some 40 new phone models in various price ranges due to launch in 2005. title: Open to Big Acquisitions
claim: Cisco Systems Inc., already one of the most acquisitive high-technology companies, is open to doing larger deals than its usual range of smaller purchases, Chief Technology Officer Charles Giancarlo said on Wednesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Cisco Systems Inc., already one of the most acquisitive high-technology companies, is open to doing larger deals than its usual range of smaller purchases, Chief Technology Officer Charles Giancarlo said on Wednesday.   “Our preference will continue to be the small companies but we would not rule out (an) unusual activity,” Giancarlo told the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco. “We remain open to it but a lot of the conditions have to be right.”   The long-term focus, he said, remained smaller companies with unique skills sets, either those directly involved with the same markets as Cisco or with products that he described as “adjacent” to theirs. Cisco is the world’s largest maker of equipment to route Internet traffic.   The company has done more than 80 acquisitions since 1993, though many of those deals have been smaller in scope, either financially or in terms of the size of operations acquired. In fact, Giancarlo lampooned some of the attention Cisco gets for its acquisition strategy.   “I’m always amazed about the rumors that we’re just about to buy XYZ,” he said. title: nfazed by Sluggish European Growth
claim: Recent economic data showing that European growth could be sluggish this year has not influenced Nokia's outlook for the year, the chief financial officer of the world's biggest mobile phone maker said on Wednesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Recent economic data showing that European growth could be sluggish this year has not influenced Nokia’s outlook for the year, the chief financial officer of the world’s biggest mobile phone maker said on Wednesday.   “In 2004 (European growth) was certainly less than robust, but the market for infrastructure and handsets was quite robust in Europe,” Nokia CFO Rick Simonson said at the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco.   “We’ve made our view of the 2005 outlook for both devices and infrastructure ... saying the conditions that existed in 2004 largely look to be repeated ... globally,” he added.   “We are not seeing any major changes economically that would cause us to shift our view.”   Nokia expects the global handset market to grow by around 10 percent in unit volumes in 2005, and at a slower pace than that in terms of value. It sees the market for network infrastructure up slightly in euro terms.   Europe remains a key market for the company, with the U.K. and Germany among its most important in terms of sales.   Fresh euro zone data on Wednesday showed that output stumbled in the latter half of 2004. Accordingly, analysts expect the European Central Bank to revise down its growth forecast for 2005 and 2006.   Eurostat reported that gross domestic product growth slowed to a 0.2 percent quarter-on-quarter rate in both the third and fourth quarters, robbing the economy of momentum into early 2005.   On Asia, Simonson said that Nokia would be largely unscathed if China’s yuan currency were allowed to float more freely at “reasonable” levels.   The United States has urged Beijing to allow its currency to move more freely. It complains that the yuan, also called the renminbi, is undervalued, giving Chinese exporters an unfair advantage in U.S. markets by keeping the dollar price of their exports cheap.   “If there was a revaluation, a valuation up of the renminbi, in the ranges that people would say would be reasonable, it would have an immaterial effect on Nokia,” Simonson said. title: M&A Likely, Telecom May Lead Charge
claim: Consolidation is warranted in nearly every sector of the technology industry, but telecommunications is likely to lead the charge out of sheer necessity, according to executives from some of the leading U.S. technology companies.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Consolidation is warranted in nearly every sector of the technology industry, but telecommunications is likely to lead the charge out of sheer necessity, according to executives from some of the leading U.S. technology companies.   Telecom hardware makers, struggling with a shrinking customer base as telecom service providers merge, could be forced to execute deals of their own this year, executives predicted at the Reuters Technology Summit.   Some of the biggest players in the sector like Nortel Networks Corp., Motorola Inc. and Siemens AG haven’t resized their businesses to reflect their smaller customer base and their supply chains and product lines aren’t correctly oriented, said Flextronics International Ltd. Chief Executive Michael Marks.   “This is why this is the year that the telecom hardware guys have to merge, there’s just not enough growth in the market,” Marks said.   Corning Inc. Vice Chairman and Chief Financial Officer Jim Flaws said he’d been expecting consolidation in both the telecommunications service provider and hardware-making segments for quite a while.   “I’d be stunned if a year from now, there wasn’t more,” Flaws said.   But in the optical fiber-making industry — one of the sectors in which Corning competes — Flaws saw little, if any, pending merger activity. While there are around eight competitors in the sector, many of them are parts of bigger companies and none is showing a willingness to give leeway or sell out to their competitors, he said.   The electronics manufacturing services sector (EMS) could see some merger activity this year, the executives said, though the urgency isn’t quite as strong.   “We are not at the place yet where we’re forced to merge because we don’t have any revenue growth, which is really where the telecom carriers are — and the telecom hardware companies,” Marks said.   There may be room for a deal within the next year or two between EMS market leaders including Flextronics, Sanmina-SCI Corp., Solectron Corp., Celestica Inc. or Jabil Circuit Inc., but activity is even more likely among the market’s smaller players.   Marks said investors are skeptical about the maturing EMS industry, where once-rapid end-market growth has sagged and trading multiples have contracted based on fears over growth in the future.   “To an investor, this is still a sloppy industry,” he said. “There’s almost certainly going to be some M&A in our space.”   The number of EMS players could shrink from around 12 today to as few as eight, Marks predicted, and deal flow particularly among the smaller firms could start this year.   “I’d expect some consolidation,” Celestica CEO Stephen Delaney agreed, though he felt it was more likely to happen if pricing dynamics shifted as too many competitors competed for little or no growth.   “But are we there yet? It kind of feels like it’s a little bit too early,” Delaney said.   Marks said Flextronics had no current plans to be acquisitive because it’s busy absorbing the purchase of Nortel’s manufacturing operation. But he also said Flextronics’ balance sheet is cleaner than those of some of its rivals.   “I’m not saying we wouldn’t participate when the time comes,” Marks said.   The semiconductor sector is also likely to condense over the longer term, Micron Technology Inc. CEO Steve Appleton said, although he said the recent recovery would probably deter deals for this year, at least. Micron, the No. 2 global computer memory chip maker, isn’t likely to be one of the assets acquired, he added.   “I think the probabilities are high there will be continuing consolidation all the way down the curve,” Appleton said. “If the market were to collapse any time soon, you absolutely would see a consolidation occur.”   He pointed to South Korea’s Hynix Semiconductor Inc. and Germany’s Infineon Technologies as two potential takeover targets and said Micron would look at acquisition opportunities if any became clear. Micron and Hynix have held talks over a merger in the past. title: s by N-Gage Despite Troubles
claim: Finnish cell phone giant Nokia will stand by its N-Gage gaming phone despite the device's slow adoption by the market, and even as the company broadens gaming throughout its phone lineup, Chief Financial Officer Rick Simonson said Wednesday.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Finnish cell phone giant Nokia will stand by its N-Gage gaming phone despite the device’s slow adoption by the market, and even as the company broadens gaming throughout its phone lineup, Chief Financial Officer Rick Simonson said Wednesday.   Despite competition in the handheld game market from the likes of Sony Corp. and Nintendo Co. plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Sprint, the No. 3 U.S. mobile provider, could consider buying back some of its shares as a way to use cash once its acquisition of Nextel Communications Inc. is over, Sprint Chief Operating Officer Len Lauer said.   Sprint, which plans to buy rival Nextel this year, will preserve cash for a time after the deal in case it is needed for potential deal related obligations, Lauer said on late Tuesday.   But in months following the merger, Sprint will have to consider what to do with its cash, he said.   Asked whether Sprint would use cash to pay down debt,  Lauer told the Reuters Technology Summit, “I think the bigger issue (to consider) will be share buybacks.”   But there may be other needs for cash in the mean time.   For example, Nextel Partners Inc, which is about 30 percent owned by Nextel and sells Nextel-branded services, could require Sprint to buy it out as a result of the Nextel deal.   Sprint could also need cash to resolve potential breaches of non-compete agreements with its own affiliates, which sell services under the Sprint brand in many markets where the Nextel-brand services are also available.   Options cited by analysts include anything from a Sprint purchase of its affiliates, which include companies such as Alamosa and US Unwired Inc., to an exchange of customers between Nextel Partners and affiliates. title: ices Firms Eye U.S. Acquisitions

plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Fast-growing Indian outsourcing and services companies are considering acquiring U.S. assets to gain quick access to new technology, but cultural differences and integration challenges have forestalled large deals.   Indian services providers such as Tata Consultancy Services Ltd., Infosys Technologies Ltd., and Wipro Ltd. have established themselves as competent providers of low-profit-margin services such as software maintenance, payroll processing and call center management.   They are now fighting for a larger slice of more lucrative work such as software development, technology consulting and enterprise software implementation.   “If they want to move up the food chain, this is the way — to buy customer relationships,” Bhanu Singh, a partner at management consulting firm Bain & Co., said at the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco. “You will see more Indian services companies buying U.S companies.”   Shares of Indian companies are hovering at multi-year highs as the firms have shown 40 percent to 50 percent annual revenue growth.   But do not expect the Indian companies to splurge.   “Indian companies are frantic about how much they want to pay because of their low cost model,” Singh added.   Indian firms have started with acquisitions mostly smaller than $100 million.   Arup Gupta, U.S. chief executive of Tata Consultancy, told the summit that his company already had workers around the world and did not anticipate large acquisitions just to increase its presence in a particular geography.   “But we do want to fill in the gaps we have in technology such as grid computing and utility computing,” he said.   Grid computing and utility computing involve sharing computers and is a key part of computer resource outsourcing where customers can contract for scalable resources from outside providers.   Indian companies have refrained from large deals because cross-border services mergers are difficult to carry out, analysts said.   IBM’s sale of its PC business to China’s Lenovo Group has set an example for Chinese and Indian companies to buy U.S. assets. But merging a U.S. firm into an Indian services company is more problematic, analysts said.   “Cultural challenges in merging services companies are quite significant, greater than the hurdles involved in selling off a product business to a foreign company,” Rod Bourgeois, an analyst with Bernstein, said.   Security is a major concern. SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Sprint wireless phone users who lose their mobile devices will be able to have the handsets shut down so that no one can access their phone numbers and other data inside, the company’s president said on Tuesday.   As part of new security features that Sprint, the No. 3 U.S. wireless carrier, will make available this year, the company will also provide anti-virus software updates “over the air” to users as new viruses targeting handheld devices are released, President and Chief Operating Officer Len Lauer told the Reuters Technology Summit.   Wireless device makers are adding security features to phones in the face of a small but growing threat of mobile phone viruses. Cabir, the world’s first mobile phone virus “in the wild,” spread to the United States in February after surfacing nine months ago in the Philippines. Cabir has many variants and generally drains cell phone batteries.   The mobile-virus threat is small at the moment but will grow in the future as virus writers become more sophisticated and phones standardize on technologies that make it easier for viruses to spread across not just specific devices but the whole industry. title: mit-Web Search Technology Still in Early Stages
claim: Web search technology and services still have a long way to go to fulfill users' needs, executives at Microsoft and Yahoo said on Tuesday.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Web search technology and services still have a long way to go to fulfill users’ needs, executives at Microsoft and Yahoo said on Tuesday.   “It’s still early in this category,” Christopher Payne, the vice president in charge of search at Microsoft Corp.’s MSN Internet division, said at the Reuters Technology Summit.   Microsoft Corp. recently launched its own search engine, Yahoo Corp. revamped its search-based advertising services on Tuesday, and Google Inc. has steadily added new features to its popular Web search engine, including the ability to search for video content.   The face-off between these three companies in the search arena is one of the most closely watched contests in the technology and Internet industry.   “If you think about the future, it is about content, it is about search,” Yahoo Chief Operating Officer Dan Rosensweig. said.   In response to Google’s emergence as the Web’s most popular search engine, as well as a lucrative business model based on text advertising displayed alongside search results, Microsoft and Yahoo have ramped up their technologies to grab a chunk of the estimated $5 billion search services market.   “We have been in the search business for a year now. Search is continuing to evolve pretty dramatically,” Rosensweig said, adding that Yahoo is incorporating content from its other Web-based services into search results.   Yahoo is opening up its search engine so that other programmers can develop software applications that tap into search information. Yahoo also said the Overture business, which it acquired in 2003 to offer search-based advertising, would be rebranded as Yahoo Search Marketing Solutions.   Despite claims that search engines are still in their infancy, Microsoft’s Payne said it would be difficult for any new players to enter the playing field and change the game, much as Google did after it debuted in 1998.   “It will be difficult to do what Google did,” Payne said. “The cost now of getting into this category is high.”   Payne said Microsoft’s research division, which has an annual budget of nearly $7 billion, has been given search as a top priority. He said the company would eventually work to make search a more integral part of the Windows, beginning with the next version of the desktop operating system, code-named Longhorn, due out in 2006.   With regard to newer search-related services, all three companies have released trial versions of search software that allow users to search through files and information stored on their hard drives.   The next step is to tailor search results to a user’s particular interests and needs, Payne said.   “Every search (right now) is like a blind date,” Payne said.   Both executives said there was an opportunity to expand search services by delivering such capabilities to cell phones.   Payne said wireless search services were a potential growth area, but it was not yet clear how search providers would be able to make money from such services. title: r the Wicked or the Weary or Tech CEO
claim: Sinking prices. A fruitless search for new ideas. Products that pass their technological prime far too quickly.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Sinking prices. A fruitless search for new ideas. Products that pass their technological prime far too quickly.   These are the fears that keep technology executives awake, these are the fears that make them quake. They are part of the frightful realization that no matter how big the cash stockpile or how well-trained the work force, no chief executive is ever truly in control.   In interviews with Reuters, several senior executives of suppliers of software, hardware and technology services described a litany of worries that keep them up at night.   In the rapidly changing world of technology, when one year’s hit could be next year’s dud, the fear of watching one’s products lose customer interest was a common theme discussed by the executives, speaking at the Reuters Technology Summit.   Freescale Semiconductor Inc., which was recently spun off by Motorola Inc., has existed just a few months as an independent entity. When asked what keeps him up at night, newly installed Chief Executive Michel Mayer barely hesitated: “So many things! How do you make sure that a few years from now what you have is still in demand?”   He said he feels an ongoing push to keep costs down so as to keep the company’s products priced competitively.   “What keeps me up is, how do I keep my company competitive from a cost point of view?” Mayer said.   Looming above most fears was perhaps the greatest concern of all: not innovating quickly enough.   “What keeps most of the executives up at night is really thinking about how do we get more innovative ideas out on the market,” said John Chen, chief executive of Sybase Inc., which sells database software to businesses. “There’s not really any big exciting ideas today.”   Take the personal computer. Despite hundreds of millions of computers sold each year, the biggest innovation in PC technology seems to be making them smaller and cheaper, not finding an innovative new use for them, Chen said.   “There are how many ways to add value to the PC?” he asked. “Right now it’s just ‘Get cheaper machines, get more powerful, smaller footprints.’ What we’re doing is meaningful but not exciting.”    Halfway around the world in India, where hundreds of thousands of newly graduated engineers are waking up each day to jobs handling business services for U.S. companies, the notion of pricing pressure isn’t a fear, it’s a business model.   But even Tata Consultancy Services, India’s biggest software services exporter, has its own fears about the matter. Facing increased competition from new local entrants, a top TCS executive said he tosses and turns about his services becoming low-value commodities.   Arup Gupta, the head of TCS’s North American operation, said he worries that the company’s growing expertise in areas such as stock exchange technology is not boosting the company’s reputation, which remains largely tied to India’s perceived chief asset as a place where engineers will work for pennies on the dollar.   The solution? title: mit-Vonage Sees Future in Wireless
claim: Vonage Holdings Corp., the largest seller of consumer Internet-based telephone service, said on Tuesday it was exploring ways to allow its customers to use the service over cellular phone networks.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Vonage Holdings Corp., the largest seller of consumer Internet-based telephone service, said on Tuesday it was exploring ways to allow its customers to use the service over cellular phone networks.   Vonage Chairman and Chief Executive Jeffrey Citron said the company had held talks for roaming agreements with all the major cellular companies, but the technological hurdles remained high.   Vonage’s customers plug phones into specially designed Internet adapters that convert voice calls into data sent over the Web, a technology that Vonage sees as more efficient than dedicated voice lines that traditional phones use.   Later this year, Vonage will offer a telephone handset with Vonage software that transmits calls over Wi-Fi wireless Internet connections. Citron said that while the handset was not meant to replace a cell phone, Vonage would eventually like to have such handsets be able to use cellular networks.   “Further out, a couple of years down the road, it may very well be a business for us,” Citron said at the Reuters Technology Summit. “I’m really thinking of ‘06 and ‘07 as we grow up as a company.”   Several companies have explored the possible merging of cellular networks with Wi-Fi usage in a portable telephone, aiming to offer cheaper mobile calls.   SBC Communications has said its Cingular Wireless joint venture will offer cell phones in a few years that will be able to make calls over home Wi-Fi networks running SBC’s high-speed Internet service.   Towerstream, a start-up wireless Internet service provider, said on Tuesday it would test a wide-area Wi-Fi network in New York designed with voice over Wi-Fi calling in mind.   Citron said it would make sense for a cellular service company to partner with Vonage for such a service because of Vonage’s large customer base. Vonage said in January it had hit 400,000 lines, and Citron said the company’s growth rate had accelerated during the first quarter to “well over” 10,000 lines per week.   Privately-held Vonage has raised $208 million in venture capital to date, and Citron said the company has about $100 million on hand. By renting network resources, Vonage has kept its capital costs low. It spends much of its free cash flow on marketing to attract new users.   Citron declined to comment on the company’s prospects for an initial public offering. He did say the market for consumer voice over Internet protocol, or VOIP, would consolidate as minor players pull out, and that Vonage would consider acquisitions but does not see much worth buying at this point.   Vonage has seen some of its customers’ calls blocked by their Internet service provider. Citron said two or three companies had blocked some of Vonage’s traffic, and that it could be up to Congress to mandate open access to U.S. broadband networks.   “We really view it as a censorship problem,” Citron said. “If these operators are going to go through and doing this to VOIP, what stops them from censoring your content?”   (News from the Reuters Technology Summit will be delivered throughout the day Monday through Wednesday to Reuters terminals and to the Reuters.com Web site, http://reuters.com) All quotes delayed a minimum of 15 minutes. title: mit: Yahoo Seeks Content as It Expands in LA - COO
claim: Yahoo Inc. is expanding in Los Angeles and inking content deals with television producers, but don't look for YahooTV, Chief Operating Officer Dan Rosensweig said on Tuesday.
plaintext: SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Yahoo Inc. is expanding in Los Angeles and inking content deals with television producers, but don’t look for YahooTV, Chief Operating Officer Dan Rosensweig said on Tuesday.   Yahoo has been embracing Hollywood since hiring former Hollywood studio chief Terry Semel to run the Sunnyvale, California-based company in 2001. Earlier this year, Yahoo said it would double its presence in Los Angeles to be closer to the action.   “Why not be where the center of creativity is, where those partnerships can be?” Rosensweig said at the Reuters Technology Summit, noting that the company has about 2,000 employees in Southern California, primarily in its Web search advertising unit.   Yahoo in November hired Lloyd Braun, a former chairman of Walt Disney Co.’s ABC Entertainment Television Group, to head its media and entertainment division, sparking speculation that the company could be moving into television.   “We don’t intend to replace TV. TV does a great job of being TV,” said Rosensweig, who added that online entertainment is now brimming with opportunities, from music and online gaming to traditional and user-generated content — areas where Yahoo already has businesses.   Rosensweig declined to predict what shape the company’s entertainment strategy would take, but said he did expect to see more deals like the one struck in September with reality television outfit Mark Burnett Productions.   “A great deal of it is going to be continued partnerships with big content providers,” Rosensweig said.   As part of the deal with Burnett, Yahoo integrates exclusive content from “The Apprentice” television show throughout its site. title: uisitions, Some Product Cuts
claim: Computer Associates International Inc. will buy companies to drive growth, but it aims to slowly whittle down its products portfolio, Chief Operating Officer Jeff Clarke said on Monday.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Computer Associates International Inc. will buy companies to drive growth, but it aims to slowly whittle down its products portfolio, Chief Operating Officer Jeff Clarke said on Monday.   “The industry is consolidating, there are lots of opportunities,” Clarke told the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco, adding that the company is particularly interested in management software and identity-control products.   Computer Associates, one of the world’s largest software makers, has grown over the years through more than 50 acquisitions, but it has refrained from large deals as it contended with government investigation into its accounting. Clarke said CA aimed for more acquisitions.   The company, based in Islandia, New York, has accelerated the consolidation of its existing portfolio of more than 2,000 products. Clarke said the company plans to shave about 5 percent to 10 percent of products annually, and more than that for the next couple of years. It plans to more than make up the lost revenue through organic growth and acquisitions.   Analysts have said the strategy makes sense because Computer Associates’ main businesses — system management and storage software — are not growing much.   “Growing the business itself is very hard,” said Nistan Hargin, an analyst with Friedman, Billings, Ramsey.   Clarke said Computer Associates’ balance sheet is the strongest it has been in eight years. CA recently named two executives to focus on acquisitions.   “We’ve traditionally used our cash for acquisitions,” Clarke said. “For acquisitions under $1 billion it will be more accretive to our shareholders if we use cash.”   CA’s stock has risen since it settled federal accounting fraud charges in September. But Clarke said he believes the stock is still undervalued, so he prefers to use cash to buy companies. Computer Associates will look for deals that would add to its cash flow cash flow within a year or two, he said.   Susquehanna Financial Group analyst Gregg Moskowitz said, “As long as they pay attention to the return on capital, then an acquisition is likely to be a positive.”   In the past year, Computer Associates has changed most of its executive suite, bringing in IBM veteran John Swainson as its CEO and Dell’s Chief Accounting Officer Robert Davis as CFO.   Its former CEO Sanjay Kumar was indicted and former CFO Ira Zar pleaded guilty to charges related to the accounting problems last year. title: ees Margin Targets in 18 Months
claim: Newly public microchip maker Freescale Semiconductor Ins. should be able to hit its broad target range for profit margins within a year and a half, Chief Executive Michel Mayer said on Monday.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Newly public microchip maker Freescale Semiconductor Ins. should be able to hit its broad target range for profit margins within a year and a half, Chief Executive Michel Mayer said on Monday.   Mayer said inventory problems that plagued the chip sector in 2004 were still being worked through in the networking segment, but his company’s exposure was less severe than that of some competitors.   Freescale’s general target is to produce gross profit margins at 45 percent at the peaks of chip industry cycles and about 40 percent at the bottom of those cycles, Mayer said.   “I’d be disappointed if I’m not there in say 18 months or less,” Mayer said at the Reuters Technology Summit. “It’s not five years.”   Freescale, spun off from Motorola Inc. in a two-part process that started with its IPO last July, derives about half of its business from the automotive segment and home appliances, while the rest is a mix of computer processing and chips for cellular handsets.   Mayer said the phone chip market appeared to be too crowded, especially as third-generation, or 3G, high-speed networks are put in place.   “TI, Qualcomm, us, Infineon, ST Micro, Broadcom, Intel — there’s a lot of competition for something that’s pretty clearly defined and has quite a lot of investment,” he said.   “That’s a space where frankly as we get to 3G and the dust clears I expect a few people to drop off and I expect some consolidation.”   In the meantime Mayer said he was comfortable with Freescale’s inventory levels, running around 10-1/2 to 11 weeks, though he said there was still overhang from 2004, where distributors found themselves oversupplied.   “In networking there is still a little bit of flush going on probably ... so I think we’re not completely healthy yet,” Mayer said at the Reuters event in San Francisco.   And with relatively little time on its own, Mayer said he still had work to do to shape Freescale into its own entity.   “I need to create a new company, more energetic ... a little bit more oomph than Motorola Semiconductor had.”  (Additional reporting by Duncan Martell and Dan Sorid)  News from the Reuters Technology Summit will be delivered

title: U.S. Plasma TV Strategy Succeeding
claim: Japan's Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., which sells consumer devices under the Panasonic brand, said on Monday that its six month-long push to sell more plasma flat-panel televisions is going better than expected.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - Japan’s Matsushita Electric Industrial Co., which sells consumer devices under the Panasonic brand, said on Monday that its six month-long push to sell more plasma flat-panel televisions is going better than expected.   “We have kept the number one position in plasma TV sales (at U.S. retailers) for 25 of the last 26 weeks,” Yoshi Yamada, chief executive of Matsushita’s North American subsidiary, told the Reuters Technology Summit in San Francisco.   Matsushita’s regional unit here was renamed Panasonic Corporation of North America last year to better reflect its brand and reach in the market, Yamada said.   Although Matsushita is a leader in Japan’s cellphone market and posted a 24 percent jump in operating profit in its latest fiscal quarter on strong sales of home appliances, the company as a whole is putting its focus domestically and internationally on growing its plasma TV business, Yamada said.   Matsushita made a strategic decision to use plasma technology, costs more,  for televisions larger than 37 inches to deliver better-quality pictures, Yamada said.   While some U.S. consumers may prefer to buy flat-panel televisions for in the $1,500 range, many are also willing to spend nearly twice that amount for better quality, Yamada said.   “To the same extent there are so many people who are looking for the product beyond the price” such as features, performance and trust in the brand, Yamada said.   For Panasonic’s next fiscal year, which begins in April, Yamada said that he expects plasma TV sales to grow two and a half times from the previous year as the company triples its advertising budget. Yamada did not provide specific sales figures.   Several analysts have recently cut their investment ratings on Matsushita due to concerns its earnings will be weighed down by sluggish demand for semiconductors, slower growth in its mobile phone division and sliding prices of consumer electronics.   Despite adopting the Panasonic brand as its main identity in North America, Yamada said that there were no plans to introduce the company’s cell phones or home appliances here.   “We are not chasing all markets at one time,” Yamada said, “I don’t think it is the right time at the moment.”  Additional reporting by Eric Auchard in San Francisco and

title: See Few Innovations as Cash Builds
claim: U.S. technology executives see mounting piles of cash but limited areas for new investment, which may fuel further consolidation in the sector, executives said at the Reuters Technology Summit.
plaintext:
SAN FRANCISCO (Reuters) - U.S. technology executives see mounting piles of cash but limited areas for new investment, which may fuel further consolidation in the sector, executives said at the Reuters Technology Summit.   “There’s not really any big exciting ideas today,” Sybase Inc. Chief Executive John Chen told the summit in San Francisco on Monday. “What we’re doing is meaningful but not exciting.”   Asked how many big innovations were around the corner in consumer electronics, Panasonic Corp. North America Chief Executive Yoshi Yamada said, “How many? None.” Panasonic is a unit of Matsushita Electric Industrial Co Ltd. .   And in a report released on Monday at the summit, Gartner Inc. warned that the $200-billion-a-year semiconductor industry should brace for two years of overcapacity and increased price pressure.   “We’re returning now to a more stable growth rate of 3 to 5 percent. We’ve become a mature industry,” Gartner analyst Martin Reynolds told Reuters.   Goldman Sachs analyst Laura Conigliaro said fast-growing sectors like storage could consolidate. Apple Computer Inc. with its iPod and disk drive maker Seagate Technology, which can’t keep up demand for its latest disk drives, are notable exceptions in her sector, she said.   “Everyone is looking for something that is exciting and they don’t see it,” she said at a Goldman Sachs technology conference last week.   Some companies are looking for ways to invest.   A Reuters Estimates study of cash holdings at the top 2,000 global tech companies shows that nearly two-thirds of the $432 billion held by these companies at the end of last year is in the hands of the top 50.   The top 15 companies alone hold more cash than the bottom 1,950 — $174.8 billion compared with $161.6 billion, according to the study.   Heading the list is Microsoft Corp., with twice the cash of second-ranked Intel. Nokia follows in third position, then Hewlett-Packard Co., Motorola Inc., Ericsson, IBM, Dell Inc., Oracle Corp., Canon Inc., Alcatel and Apple.   But the number of companies with cash to make a buy are limited. Only 73 have more than $1 billion in cash.   “When industries mature, scale starts to matter,” said Michel Mayer, chief executive of Freescale Semiconductor Inc., the third-largest U.S. electronic chipmaker, which was spun off in 2004 by Motorola.   “Consolidation is probably coming, with prices moving lower,” Kip Bedard, investor relations director of Micron Technology Inc., said of expected declines in memory chips, Micron’s core business.   For its own part, Micron remains well-heeled with about $1.2 billion in cash.   (Additional reporting by Duncan Martell)  News from the Reuters Technology Summit will be delivered
